title: Progressive Sensorineural Hearing Loss Secondary to Arnold-Chiari Malformation
chief_complaint: Parents requested an evaluation due to questionable hearing loss and a mild language delay.

problem_summary.onset: Questionable hearing loss noted at age 4; confirmed progressive loss at age 6.
problem_summary.course: Progressive, particularly in high frequencies over a 15-month monitoring period.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Mild language delay; no other neurological symptoms (no nystagmus, dizziness, or hydrocephalus).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Required binaural hearing aids and an auditory trainer for school.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Identify cause of progressive loss and manage communication needs.

history.present_illness: Child was initially evaluated at age 4 at an outside clinic with borderline normal results and fair reliability. Two years later (age 6), he presented to our center with hearing loss greater than previously documented.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Sensorineural hearing loss, slightly greater in the left ear initially. High-frequency sloping configuration.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Contralateral reflexes present at normal to slightly elevated levels.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Abnormal bilaterally. Slightly extended I-II and III-V interwave intervals contributing to substantially extended I-V intervals. No significant effect of high repetition rate.

numeric_results.RE_Latencies: Wave I: 2.34ms, Wave III: 4.72ms, Wave V: 7.12ms
numeric_results.LE_Latencies: Wave I: 2.22ms, Wave III: 4.78ms, Wave V: 7.10ms

history.present_illness: Monitoring over 15 months revealed progressive hearing loss primarily in the high frequencies.
history.otologic_history: CT scans of temporal bone were normal. MRI with gadolinium showed herniation of cerebellar tonsils through foramen magnum.
history.prior_management: Fitted with binaural hearing aids; auditory trainer recommended for school.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech recognition remained excellent despite progression in pure tone thresholds.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: MRI confirmed Arnold-Chiari Malformation (ACM). Cerebellar tonsils herniated through foramen magnum; fourth ventricle positioned low. Mass lesion in right rostral medulla noted.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presented with bilateral, progressive, high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Despite excellent speech recognition scores and normal tympanometry, the ABR was abnormal bilaterally with extended interwave intervals (I-V). This neural sign prompted imaging (MRI), which identified an Arnold-Chiari Malformation (ACM) with herniation of the cerebellar tonsils. The ABR abnormality is attributed to stretching of the VIIIth nerve and brainstem compression.
counseling_points: The hearing loss is sensorineural and has shown progression over 15 months.
ABR results suggest neural involvement (stretching of the nerve) consistent with the MRI findings of Arnold-Chiari Malformation.
Neurosurgical consultation is required (decompressive craniotomy indicated).
Binaural hearing aids are necessary for hearing loss management.
An auditory trainer (FM system) and preferential seating are recommended for academic support.
notes_for_actor: Patient is a young child (approx 6-7 years old), so interactions are likely with the parents.
Parents may be concerned about the 'progressive' nature of the loss.
Emphasize that while the hearing loss is significant, speech understanding remains excellent.
The key diagnostic pivot point was the ABR; without it, the neural cause might have been missed as CT scans were normal.
